awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Predictors and consequences of early understanding of mathematical equivalence
awd_abstract_narration:
The purpose of this project is to longitudinally investigate (K-Grade 6) a child's understanding of mathematical equivalence.  This project will answer two major research questions: (1) What are the origins of individual differences in a child's early understanding of mathematical equivalence? And (2) What are the long-term consequences of having a poor understanding of mathematical equivalence?  

To answer the first research question, the PI will identify skills (early number sense, relational thinking, and cognitive flexibility) in kindergarten (Time 1 in the longitudinal design) that predict individual differences in understanding of mathematical equivalence in later grades, while controlling for gender, SES, and IQ.  To answer the second research question, the PI will measure a child's understanding of mathematical equivalence at second grade (Time 2), and then she will use this measure to predict mathematics achievement at the third, fourth, fifth, and sixth grades.  At the sixth grade, the PI will also measure algebra readiness.  For answering research question 2, the PI will control for gender, IQ, and computational fluency.  

The development of algebraic thinking is a timely topic with national and international interests.  This project takes a unique approach to explore ways to develop student algebraic thinking, especially the use of a longitudinal design.  In addition, this project is exemplary for interdisciplinary work on integrating cognitive psychology and mathematics education.  The findings from this project can have both theoretical and practical implications.

por.por_cntn:
Mathematical equivalence is the relation between two quantities that are interchangeable. It is widely regarded as an important concept for promoting children’s mathematics achievement and algebra readiness. Unfortunately, many elementary school children in the U.S. struggle to understand this concept, both when it is presented in concrete form (e.g., with blocks and word problems) and when it is presented in symbolic form (e.g., 3 + 4 = 5 + 2). Historically, children’s difficulties were attributed to age-related limitations in children’s memory and reasoning, but researchers now generally agree that difficulties are due, at least in part, to the way arithmetic is traditionally taught in school. Despite the field’s progress in understanding why children struggle to understand mathematical equivalence, two critical questions have remained unanswered until now. First, what are the origins of individual differences in children’s early understanding of mathematical equivalence? We know that most elementary school children struggle to understand mathematical equivalence; however, a substantial minority develops a good understanding, despite attending the same schools and receiving the same experiences with arithmetic. No research until this project had examined the factors that give rise to these individual differences. Second, what are the long-term consequences of gaining an understanding of mathematical equivalence in elementary school? The general assumption is that an early understanding of mathematical equivalence leads to greater mathematics achievement and algebra readiness down the road. However, this key assumption had not been tested until now. The PI and her research team addressed both of these gaps by conducting two longitudinal studies. The first was designed to test if three skills in kindergarten (cognitive flexibility/executive functioning, relational thinking, and number sense) predict individual differences in understanding of mathematical equivalence in second and fourth grade after controlling for gender, SES, and IQ. The second was designed to test if an early understanding of mathematical equivalence predicted later mathematics achievement and algebra readiness after controlling for gender, SES, IQ, and arithmetic calculation skill.

In terms of the potential origins of individual differences in understanding of mathematical equivalence, findings pointed to three kindergarten skills: cognitive flexibility/executive functioning, relational thinking, and one of the specific number sense skills— number sets identification. These three kindergarten skills predicted future children’s understanding of mathematical equivalence even after controlling for all of the other studied factors. However, there were some differences in the type of understanding of mathematical equivalence each factor predicted. Children’s relational thinking was important for predicting concrete, but not formal symbolic, understanding of mathematical equivalence. Children’s number sets identification was important for predicting formal symbolic, but not concrete, understanding of mathematical equivalence. And finally, cognitive flexibility/executive functioning was important for predicting both concrete and formal symbolic understanding of mathematical equivalence. The relation was positive in all cases, and importantly, the findings were specific to understanding of mathematical equivalence (e.g., the significant kindergarten skills did not predict reading fluency in fourth grade).

In terms of the long-term consequences of gaining an understanding of mathematical equivalence in elementary school, findings suggest that early understanding matters. Specifically, children’s concrete understanding of mathematical equivalence in second grade as well as the grade level at which children first acquire a formal symbolic understanding of mathematical equivalence both predict children’s mathematics achievement in 5th grade and their algebra readiness in 6th grade after controlling for gender, SES, IQ, and arithmetic calculation skill. The relation was positive for concrete understanding of math equivalence (the better the concrete understanding in second grade, the better the math achievement and algebra readiness), but negative for the grade-of-acquisition of formal symbolic understanding (the earlier the grade of acquisition, the better the math achievement and algebra readiness). Again, these results were specific to mathematics achievement (e.g., understanding of math equivalence in either form did not predict reading fluency in fifth grade). Results support the mathematics education community’s idea that mathematical equivalence is a foundational concept that, once learned, makes it easier to learn new mathematical concepts and skills (especially in algebra), so it may deserve more attention from elementary school teachers.

Results have been disseminated through conference presentations, invited lectures, peer-reviewed publications in some of the best journals in the field, professional development sessions for teachers, presentations at local community events, and a tri-annual newsletter for parents, teachers, and school administrators that showcases research conducted by the project team and by other researchers from across the country.

The project integrated research with teaching, training, and learning by forging productive partnerships. Specifically, the PI created a successful partnership between her lab and the Notre Dame Department of Mathematics to provide an opportunity for undergraduate mathematics majors to get involved with research on the development of children’s mathematical thinking. The project also provided opportunities for teaching and mentoring of dozens of additional undergraduates, research staff members, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows, including four individuals from underrepresented groups.
